image.ImageDescription: Greg and Julie hustle down the icy 50 degree slope of Old Chute on Mount Hood.
This shop owner doesn't look too impressed with me. I got a smile afterward, don't worry.
My first glimpse of Ama Dablam through a mess of clouds on Sumdur Peak.
I'm not even sure what mountains these are, but boy do they look nice.
Even from Kala Pattar, Ama stands singular.
A stupa gleams through the mist north of Thame.
Hang on kid! If this boy is half as annoying as I was as a child, I don't know how dad hasn't dropped the bike yet.
Doing its best to disperse the clouds, the sun lights up the low slopes of Kongde Ri's eastern ridge.
Phurba spins some massive prayer wheels after the puja at Schechen Monastery in Boudha, Kathmandu.
The thin summit of Island Peak gets you up close and personal with Lhotse.
A tattoo artist poses outside of Mohan's Tattoo Studio in Thamel, Kathmandu.
Clouds hang threateningly over the Lulka airstrip.
Everest, the last thing in the entire world to catch the setting sun.
"May all conscious beings find happiness and peace!" Especially this good girl resting in front of the stupa in Boudha, Kathmandu.
Pema. What a guy.
Flying into Kathmandu, the Himalaya appear as ghosts on the wing.
Tengkangpoche peeks out from behind the clouds as we climb Sumdur Peak.
Resting on the road from Khumjung to Thame
Ama Dablam greets us as we descend from the Cho La Pass.
A rider climbs the steep stone path towards Namche Bazaar.
Juggin'.
The imposing east fast of Lobuche East.
Pema introduces me to the mighty Bhote Khosi Khola, the river that runs the length of the Nongpa Valley.
The north face of Cho La Tse catches the morning light.
Gokyoooooo! We're coming!
Alex watches the sun rise over the Cascades from high on Rainier's Ingraham Glacier.
Cho La Tse and Tabuche watch over the town of Gokyo from afar.
Crossing Gokyo lake as Cho Oyu catches the morning glow.
Bracing ourselves as the wind pelts us with snow on the path to Mera Peak high camp.
Serzhang, the teacher of the Panggom Monastery, chants during the puja
Feeling good on the descent from Ice Lake, with the peak of Annapurna 1 just visible
Ploughing the fields, shoes optional.
Karma clips Diem into fixed lines in front of a sea of undulating glaciers on Mera Peak's summit
Red Sky in the Morning: clouds from the south vault over the Annapurna Massif and catch the rising sun
Man on the Moon: Glen walks alone up Mera Peak's summit block to set fixed lines for the group.
The King's Seat: Nuptse, Everest, and Lhotse from Mera Peak High Camp.
As we descended slushy snow towards Makalu, Ang Pasang fell waist-deep in a crevasse.
The result of having to take three bigger-than-normal steps at altitude: Lindsay sprawls out and recovers her breath.
Glen takes a productive break as the sun rises over Kyashar, high on the summit push of Mera Peak.
Lhakpa Kaji shoots me a cheesy grin as he pays his respects during the Panggom Duwa Puja ceremony
High on the Thorong La, with Chulu West in the background
Ngima, a prominent monk, dances for the final day of the puja.
Pasang Dawa shows off his crampons.
The Tashi Sangag Chholing Gumba framed against a perfect sunset
Jangbu climbs his first pitch of ice on the retreating flanks of a glacier on the Mera La pass.
Red Sky in the Morning: clouds from the south vault over the Annapurna Massif and catch the rising sun
